THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER 8937F6, QS MIKRO DAGITIM AS, SERIFALI MAH.EMIN SK.HEY PLAZA BLOK NO:51-7, UMRANIYE-ISTANBUL TURKEY 34000.

item.title: Report E-2024010389
item.description:
Report E-2024010389

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-24T15:11:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-18
  • City: RICHLAND
  • State: MS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LJS experienced a UN3286 EC1417A release from a 350-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the trailer floor as well as the tote body. The lid to the tote was not secure causing a release. The tote and impacted trailer floor were wiped down and cleaned with simple green. All impacted pads and PPE were then placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The crew removed and cleaned the gasket which was then reseated, they then tightened the bolts and conducted a slosh test to ensure there would be no further release. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:
Report E-2024010399

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-24T15:11:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-16
  • City: CHICAGO
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 16, 2024, one (1) 225-gallon tote of UN2922 was crushed in transit and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the UN2922-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum to be staged onsite for future disposal. HCE personnel transferred the product from the 255-gallon tote into one (1) 330-gallon tote for further shipment.

item.title: Report E-2024010386
item.description:
Report E-2024010386

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-24T15:11:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-17
  • City: CHEROKEE
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: AIRGAS USA, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver encountered deteriorating roadway conditions on his way to make delivery to the customer. At some point driver claims that a 3rd party driver veered into his lane causing him to take minor evasive action. This lead to loss of control when he contacted an icy road surface. The tanktruck rolled into the median where it came to rest. Ther was a rupture of a vapor valve as well as the diesel fuel tank. Luckily due to the cold weather only minor amounts of ammonia were lost through the vapor break. The police and local fire department were called to the scene to set up roadblocks and control the area. The Huntsville, AL Hazmat team eventually made it to the site to assess the situation. It was deemed feasible to set the truck upright and tow away to a remote location for product offload and depressurization. Fugitive vapors were controlled by water application by the FD. A fuel cleanup team has been assigned to remove soil and diesel fuel as well.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-24T15:11:38+00:00

  • City: EL PASO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 19, 2024, at 2053 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal LEP. It was reported that approximately 1-gallon of El Pinol 85 (Pine Oil 60%) UN1272 was released from 55-gallon metal drum due to pinhole puncture. The release impacted the dock and trailer floor. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and they felt comfortable that terminal personnel was capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on-site. The terminal did not have a drum large enough to overpack the damaged drum that was leaking. ERTS dispatched contractors to drop off an 85-gallon metal drum for terminal personnel. Once arrived, terminal personnel placed the damaged drum and all impacted absorbents into the drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: 1. X-2024010418 A HAZMAT AUDITOR CAME BY AND SAID ONE OF THE HAZMATS ON THEIR TRAM HAD A STRONG CHEMICAL SELL AND POINTED TO A HAZMAT WITH BOTH CLASS 5.1 AND 8 DIAMONS HAZARD LABELS. OPENING AND INSPECTING THE PACKAGE RESPONDER FOUND 4 1GAL CONTAINERS WITH VENTED CAPS. ONE OF THE CAPS WAS MISSING THE PAPER SEAL UNDERNEATH WHICH ALLOWED SOME OF THE LIQUID INSIDE TO DRIBBLE OUT AND WET A PORTION OF THE CARDBOARD INSIDE. 2. X-2024010419 AUDITOR NOTED A STRONG SMELL COMING FROM PACKAGE AND CONTACTED AUTITOR. AUDITOR REMOVED PACKAGE TO THE DMP PROCESSING FACILITY. IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT ONE INNER CONTAINER WAS MISSING THE SEAL INSERT IN THE VENTED CAP, CAUSINT THE CONTAINER TO LEAK A SMALL AMOUNT AND STAIN THE OUTER BOX. ALL CONTAINERS DISPOSED VIA DMP.

Report X-2024010490

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-23T15:11:55+00:00

  • City: EARTH CITY

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: FULLY LABELED HAZ-MAT SHIPMENT WAS VISUALLY DISCOVERED WET IN APPEARANCE BY THE HCD PICK-OFF ON THE PD-4. WITHOUT TOUCHING THE PKG HE TURNED OFF SECURED THE BELT, EVACUATED THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS IMMEDIATE SUPERVISOR. DMP WAS CONTACTED AND WITHIN 4 MINUTES A DESIGNATED RESPONDER ARRIVED DONNING THE PROPER PPE AND WITH A FULLY STOCKED SPILL CART. AFTER FOLLOWING THE DECISION TREE APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET THE DAMAGE WAS CONTAINED (NO SPILLAGE OUTSIDE OF CARTON), THEN TRANSPORTED TO THE DMP PROCESSING AREA. CLOSER INSPECTION REVEALED THAT THE CAP ON 1 OF 6 POLY 2-LITER DISPENSER/CONTAINERS WAS SLIGHTLY AJAR, CAUSING APPROX. 12 OUNCES OF THE LIQUID TO LEAK THROUGH THE BREACH AND INTO THE CARTON. THERE WAS NO INTERNAL PACKING MATERIAL AND THE OUTER CARTON WAS A SINGLEWALL FIBERBOARD BOX, RATED AT A 275 LBS/IN BURSTING TEST.

  • City: BRUNSWICK

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SAFETY-KLEEN SYSTEMS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: This was the last pick up for the day and when the driver was doing his pick up the customer added more paint waste to the drum and he loaded it on his truck. The drive was about an hour back to the facility to unload for the end of the day. He arrive at approximately 1730 and when he opened the door to unload they noticed the drum was swelling up. The team at the facility emidiatly called for a team to come out and and address the container. The drum expanded to the point of failure at about 1830 before the team could arrive to address the situation. The bottom of the container failed and the contents was released into the truck with around 10 gallons making it to the pavement. They were able to contained it with absorbents and booms from spreading. The team arrived around 1930 to perform the clean up. They dawned the proper PPE and proceeded to clean up the material and overpacking the container to be shipped and disposed of properly. The crew was able to complete this around 2200.

All containers were staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XNJ reported a 5-ounce release of UN1230 Pro Methanol from a 55-gallon metal drum. The damaged drum was placed into a 65-gallon poly drum. Contractors were dispatched to place the drum into a compatible container. Contractors arrived onsite and advised they did not observe a release to the poly overpack. The damaged drum was removed from the poly overpack, patched, and re-overpacked into an 85-gallon metal drum. The poly overpack the drum was staged in was then cut up and containerized into a 55-gallon metal drum as a precaution. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On January 16, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN3149 was crushed in transit and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the trailer interior and dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel re-secured the cap on the 330-gallon tote of UN3149 that was loose. Crews then deployed granular absorbent to the impacted loading dock floor and worked them in utilizing hand tools. All UN3149 impacted material was collected and containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal by R+L.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: SequenceEvent: The box was found in the Damages Area wet and torn open. It did not have any hazardous markings, so I thought it was water/rain from that day. However, I felt a burning sensation on my wrists and discovered the liquid was battery acid. It was an undeclared HazMat and a SDS was found to confirm its hazardous status. DescribePack: The FedEx Office box was torn open and soiled. There were plastic bags of plastic Christmas ornaments spilling out (inner packing). There were also three Non-HazMat items inside, but they got battery acid on them. The battery was inside a plastic shopping bag. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: I found a SDS for the battery despite being sent Standard Domestic Residential and lacking any hazardous indications on the box. I isolated the package and processed it after knowing it was hazardous.

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 11, 2024, two (2) 55-gallon drums of UN2922 were damaged due to a fire in the unit and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the tops of the drums and the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Advanced Environmental Solutions (AES) to remediate the impacted site. AES personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted surfaces of the trailer interior and worked them in with hand tools. AES personnel then utilized absorbent wipes to wipe any residual amount of released material from the top of the drums. All UN2922 impacted material was collected and containerized in eight (8) 95-gallon overpacks with other waste that were staged on-site in RLC's designated waste area.

  • Description: On January 9, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon box of UN1824 fell in transit and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental Group (MEG) to remediate the impacted site. MEG personnel deployed granular absorbents, neutralizer and absorbent pads to the sodium hydroxide solution-impacted trailer interior and impacted pallets. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for terminal disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024010229
item.description:
Report E-2024010229

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-18T15:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-05
  • City: EL PASO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: GrayMar Environmental Services was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft- by-2ft area of the concrete trailer yard and a 10ft-by-15ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that twenty (20) gallons of material was released due to a nail puncture from a pallet during offloading that damaged one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. GrayMar Environmental Services personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas and recovered the spent material and containerized into one (1) 55- gallon metal drum. The damaged metal drum was over-packed into one (1) 65-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was stage onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: On January 10, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN3098 was damaged during shipping and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel collected one (1) damaged 5-gallon pail of UN3098 and containerized it in one (1) 55-gallon drum. Crews then deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and worked them in using hand tools. FCE personnel utilized absorbent wipes to remediate any residual product. All UN3098 impacted material was collected and containerized in three (3) 55-gallon drums for disposal by R+L.

item.description:
Report E-2024010281

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-18T15:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-10
  • City: HUNTSVILLE
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 10, 2024, two (2) 275-gallon totes of UN1866 were crushed in transit and released approximately 300-gallons of product to the trailer interior and adjacent freight. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel unloaded the trailer, wiping freight as it was being transferred out of the trailer. Crews then deployed absorbents to the paint thinner impacted trailer interior. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into 55-gallon drums for terminal disposal. HES transferred the remaining contents from the two (2) 275-gallon totes to one (1) new 275-gallon and two (2) 55-gallons drums. The damaged totes were cut into pieces and placed into two(55-gallon drums. HES removed seven (7) pallets that were damaged and/or impacted by the paint thinner. Additional damaged/impacted freight including aerosol cans of break cleaner and freon were removed and placed into 55-gallon drums for disposal. A total of 15 55-gallon drums of waste were generated and staged onsite for terminal disposal.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES personnel observed that R+L had placed granular absorbents to all impacted areas. item.title: Report E-2024010383
item.description:
Report E-2024010383

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-24T15:11:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-19
  • City: NEWBURGH
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: A DUIE PYLE INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 19, 2023, at 0711 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by A Duie Pile personnel in Newburgh, NY regarding the release of an unknown amount of various products due to a multiple vehicle accident (The speed of the vehicle is unknown). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of multiple materials which included KEM AQUA® 400 Waterborne Enamel (UN1263, 3, III), Polane Plus Enamel (Part A) (UN1263, 3, III), and a Flammable Liquid, Corrosive, n.o.s. (UN1263, 3, II). Contractors were unable to assess approximately how much of each were released due to the materials mixing with each other. Contractors were able to clean the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste generated was containerized in (7) 55-gallon poly drum, and (7) 55-gallon metal drum which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-05
  • City: GEISMAR
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 5, 2023 at 1200 hrs., FRA Hazmat Inspector discovered what appeared to be product running down the sides of PNWX 703091 (Load / UN 3082 / Class 9 / PG III) at CN Geismar Yard. The liquid on the exterior of the railcar was observed coming from the manway. The inspector climbed the railcar and attempted to turn the manway cover bolts by hand but was unsuccessful. The FRA Inspector notified the Dangerous Goods Officer. The Dangerous Goods Officer made all notifications. CN Response Contractor responded and upon approaching the railcar observed moisture on the exterior of the railcar coming from the manway area. Upon further investigation, the manway gasket was found to be pinched which did not provide proper securement of the manway closure. The manway gasket was properly installed, and manway was secured. The exterior of the railcar was decontaminated and returned to Transportation.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Driver states to BC that PH had HazMat staged on the floor and he moved to a shelf. He believes he hit a bump and it caused the package to burst on the shelf and leak in the van onto other packages. DescribePack: 1.5 gallons of Zep cleaner leaked from bottom of the Gallon bottles in fiberboard box. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Driver was instructed to pull over and open the doors of the vehicle. He called the Emergency Response number on the HazMat paperwork but was not assisted. BC met driver and they were able to transfer damaged packages in the back of a straight truck. All cleanup materials were put in a bag and given to PDM upon return. After cleanup, driver did not feel at risk and continued on with his day. Upon return to the station, PDM - Kayla Hoback - equipped PPE (mask, gloves, apron, etc.) and put all damaged packages onto a damage pallet to thoroughly inspect each one. Only 4 packages truly damaged and the remaining were repacked and sent out to customers.

  • Description: On November 25, 2023, at 1645 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by RDX, LLC personnel in Raphine, Virginia regarding the release of approximately (5) gallon of Professional Wire Wheel Cleaner (Corrosive Liquid, Toxic, N.O.S. (UN2922, 8, II) from (1) 55-gallon poly drums. Contractors were dispatched and upon arrival, contractors confirmed the material and the amount of the release. All waste generated was containerized in (1) 55-gallon poly drum which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.
